abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Project in Ireland
            has been satisfactorily implemented with the exception of
            the following changes: deletion of two comprehensive schools
            due to changed plans of the local education authorities;
            deletion of two industrial training centers due to the
            Government's decision to defer capital works during the
            poor economic climate of the 1970s; and transfer of the
            College of Commerce from the First Education Project to the
            Second. Project completion was extended by nearly 100
            percent due to: difficulties in reaching agreements with the
            local authorities over programs and sites of some of the
            comprehensive schools; problems in determining the
            respective roles of the regional technical colleges and
            industrial training centers in off-the-job apprentice
            training; and protracted national policy debate on higher
            education, affecting particularly the College of Commerce.
            The project was key in the development of a new diversified
            education pyramid in Ireland. It met appraisal targets for
            the output of apprentices, technicians, and agricultural
            technologists. The development of the technical teacher
            training institute fell short of expectations due to change
            in emphasis from short-duration courses to a new four-year
            degree program. All institutions have developed close formal
            and informal links with industry. The National Institute of
            Higher Education, Limerick successfully introduced the
            program of studies on the module and credit system and
            attracted the establishment of four industrial research and
            development centers on its campus. A well-developed
            cost-planning and control system was established within the
            Building Unit of the Department of Education. Project
            designs have been well within acceptable cost limits and
            conformed to approved area limits. The bidding process for
            furniture and equipment attracted highly competitive
            bidders, and the user staff were highly satisfied with the
            appropriateness and quality of the equipment supplied.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project comprises: (1) construction
            and equipping of (a) 14 new comprehensive secondary schools
            providing 9,660 student places in new urban growth centers
            and to replace 27 small and obsolete schools in mostly rural
            areas, and (b) five new industrial training centers
            providing 1,650 new places in lieu of the 620 places
            existing in four inadequately housed centers; (2) expansion
            of the facilities of seven existing regional technical
            colleges through adding 4,650 new places to reach a total of
            7,280 places; (3) provision of the central campus core of
            the main academic and communal facilities and equipment for
            the National Institute of Higher Education (NIHE); (4)
            providing computer equipment at NIHE and the complementary
            systems needed to service the other third level technical
            institutes included in the project; (5) provision of a new
            teacher training institute on the NIHE campus and expansion
            of its facilities to 710 places, replacing 200 places in
            five uneconomically small institutes located throughout the
            country; (6) transfer of the Faculty of Agriculture from
            inadequate existing facilities at the Lyons experimental
            station to the main campus of University College, Dublin
            providing 550 places on the campus, where new classrooms,
            laboratories, and equipment will be.
